text: deep in the Bolivian jungle there's an
animal refuge that draws a certain kind
of volunteer the sort of person who
might want to walk around the jungle
with a puma or a Jaguar and a leash as
if they were taking Rex down to the dog
park we've been very fortunate to not
have very many serious injuries or even
lost no limbs in fact with the big cats
I can't say that we've had any very
serious injuries it's no more dangerous
to volunteer here than it would be to go
and volunteer in the Sudan
this is Simona Oh metal reporting for
the New York Times from embody Bolivia
where volunteers pay $10 a day for the
privilege of helping to care for the
animals here the refuge is run by
intiwarayassi
a non-profit group that says ambu IATI
is the last resort for animals that have
nowhere else to go
it's big cats monkeys and tapirs are
often rescued from abusive private
owners or freed from the black market
each morning starts with a deep trance
session then it's on to the day's work
the big draw to this place is the
opportunity to take a stroll with a big
cat no special training required this is
probably one of the few places in the
world where you can come in as a
volunteer with little to no experience
with big animals like me I have no
experience out of it they venture into
the jungle wearing mosquito nets around
their heads as protection from swarms of
insects the chance to be able to walk
with the Puma is just such an incredible
experience and to be able to do that
every day it's just you know it's such a
gift be able to do that in the nine
years since its creation ANBU IATI
says there have been no fatalities yeah
it's a big animal they there are very
powerful animals so yeah it is little
nerve-wracking it's a little scary to
you know that you know they do have the
power to into you but that's not really
what they're trying to do they're more
curious and playful than anything
but big cats in captivity being cared
for by untrained volunteers raised
concerns among conservationists and
biologists you know the problem with
places like that they get an enormous
amount of publicity because of these
incredible opportunities to walk with
wild cats but but in fact there's not
much that actually goes to conserving
wild cats where it really needs to be
done in the big protected areas and
imperiled areas around the world
so so I think the great majority of
people like me hardcore conservation
scientists who spend their lives working
on big cats would argue that refuges
like this don't actually do much to
conserve the animal that they say
they're protecting but many of the
volunteers say their work is vital to
the cats and that they are often
misunderstood it's an experience it's
hard to put into words it's one of those
things in life that sounds cliche but it
has to be you know and as you have to
show you have to experience it too to
understand it a lot of us when we go
home we have trouble communicating to
people that that haven't been here they
haven't done this what it's like to be
here but it's it's it's a very kind of
secret world it's a privileged world and
it's one that we're fortunate enough
that our cat allow us to enter into
